description:
Clostridium amylolyticum is an anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium. It is a member of the Firmicutes phylum and the Clostridium genus, which are known for their ability to degrade complex carbohydrates.

C. amylolyticum is capable of hydrolyzing starch and other polysaccharides through the production of amylolytic enzymes. This metabolic capability allows the bacterium to thrive in environments rich in starch, such as soil and sediments. The spores of C. amylolyticum are resistant to harsh environmental conditions, including heat, desiccation, and lack of oxygen, which enables the bacterium to survive and persist in various habitats.

Taxonomically, C. amylolyticum was first isolated and described in 1986 from soil samples. It is closely related to other starch-degrading Clostridium species, such as C. acetobutylicum and C. beijerinckii, which are known for their potential applications in biofuel production and other industrial processes.

Further research on the physiology, ecology, and potential biotechnological applications of C. amylolyticum may provide insights into the role of this species in natural and engineered microbial communities.
